timeline.message: Fix improper initialization order in FabricTweaker

Fix missing class loader exclusion for *ModInitializer

These interfaces are accessed from the Entrypoint* classes which themselves are
excluded from the LaunchClassLoader. Not excluding the interfaces will cause
those to be loaded by the LaunchClassLoader as well as its parent, leading to
casting errors when mod entry points are to be invoked.

Allow FabricTweaker to operate as primary or secondary tweaker

When operating as primary tweaker, it provides all launch arguments.
When operating as secondary tweaker, it only provides the class transformer and
mod loading functionality but not the launch arguments.

This distinction is necessary because two tweakers providing arguments will
invariably lead to arguments being passed multiple times which is not allowed
for some of them.

Fix overwriting of third-party tranformations to entry point classes

We store (`patchedClasses`) and then completely substitute during loading
(`FabricTransformer.lwTranformerHook`) the bytecode for any classes which our
`EntrypointTransformer`s need to change.

Therefore, when they ask for any classes, we must explicitly pass the raw
bytecode through all other transformers in order to not miss out on their
changes.

Fix loading of deobfuscated game with FabricTweaker

See comment on preloadRemappedJar.

Add class loader exclusion for gson to FabricTweaker

See cc03fd09a786a5d8a84168fd3a88454e3e11eefc

timeline.bodyText: ClientModInitializer and DedicatedServerModInitializers have @Environment annotations. Is this exclusion going to affect their class transformation?
timeline.author: JamiesWhiteShirt

timeline.bodyText: Why? I haven't looked at this in detail, but this looks at first glance like it might cause an infinite loop. I.e. EntrypointTransformer asks to run transformers which runs the EntrypointTransformer
timeline.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText:
It's not. The EntrypointTransformer is not an actual tranformer, i.e. it's never called in response to class loading. It's merely called during bootstrap, loads the bytecode, applies its patch and then stores the result in a map.
The real transformer merely queries that map, if it has an entry (and at this point it won't), it returns that and otherwise it just delegates further.
